section: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site. i-on will use best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance between the hours of 8pm and 8am Eastern Standard Time on weekdays, or during weekends.
explanation: The initial statement promises continuous operation (24/7), but the exception for maintenance creates ambiguity. While it specifies *when* maintenance should ideally occur (8 pm to 8 am EST on weekdays or weekends), it doesn't explicitly state that maintenance *will only* occur during those times. This leaves open the possibility of maintenance at other times, potentially contradicting the 24/7 uptime promise. A clearer statement would guarantee that all maintenance will be scheduled during the specified off-peak hours, unless under emergency circumstances. Furthermore, the term "reasonable hardware and software maintenance" is ambiguous. What constitutes 'reasonable' is subjective and undefined. The contract should explicitly define what types of maintenance are covered and what constitutes a reasonable duration for such maintenance. Without this definition, i-on could potentially perform lengthy or frequent maintenance, impacting the Customer's uptime and leading to disputes.
location: Section: SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE CUSTOMER

section: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site. i-on will use best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance between the hours of 8pm and 8am Eastern Standard Time on weekdays, or during weekends.
explanation: The phrase "best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance" is vague. This does not create a concrete obligation. What constitutes 'best efforts' is subjective and open to interpretation. i-on could argue they made some attempt to schedule maintenance during off-peak hours, even if the ultimate scheduling significantly impacted the Customer's service. A stronger clause would specify concrete actions i-on must take, such as giving the customer advance notice of scheduled maintenance with a minimum number of hours or days for notification or setting maximum monthly maintenance durations. Without clearly defined obligations, the customer has little recourse if i-on schedules frequent or lengthy maintenance during peak hours.
location: Section: SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE CUSTOMER

section: up to 1 hour per month of Web site administration services at no additional charge, limited to: requests for changes to ftp/e-mail users and passwords; requests for e-mail configuration changes; modification of mail aliases; changes to server MIME types; files restored from backup; answering questions about server-side scripts; ftp configuration changes; log file configuration changes; importing or exporting of database records; and consultation on site operation and administration. Additional Web site administration services will be billed at $200 per hour.
explanation: The clause specifies "up to 1 hour per month" but doesn't clarify what happens if a request takes slightly longer than 1 hour. For example, if a file restore takes 1 hour and 5 minutes, it is unclear if the Customer will be billed for the entire second hour or only for the 5 minutes exceeding the initial hour. The term "consultation on site operation and administration" is also ambiguous. The scope of consulting services is not defined. A minor question could potentially consume the entire hour, limiting other administrative tasks, or conversely, i-on may limit consultations to trivial matters only. More clarity is needed as to the depth and breadth of consulting services provided, or a more precise list of covered consultations should be included.
location: Section: SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE CUSTOMER

section: The Customer is responsible for paying the recurring monthly fees by the 5th day of each month. The Customer acknowledges that failure to pay such fees in a timely manner will result in the interruption or discontinuation of services for the Hosted Site.
explanation: This section outlines the payment responsibility of the customer but does not specify the consequences in detail. The terms 'interruption' and 'discontinuation' of services are vague. Interruption could mean a brief suspension, while discontinuation implies a permanent termination. The contract lacks clarity on the process: Will there be a grace period after the 5th? Will the Customer receive a warning before service interruption or discontinuation? What is the process for restoring service after payment? The contract should outline a clear procedure, including notice periods, potential reconnection fees, and the timeframe within which service will be restored upon payment. Without this, i-on could abruptly terminate service on the 6th without warning.

section: The Customer is solely responsible for any and all software programs, server-side scripts, and/or executable components that are installed on the Hosting Computer for the purpose of providing interactive applications or dynamic content on the Hosted Site. Any such programs, scripts, or components that might affect the stability of the Hosting Computer or interfere with other Web sites on the Hosting Computer must be approved by i-on before being installed on the Hosted Site, i-on reserves the right to deny the Customer permission to install any such programs, scripts, or components, to require additional fees for the installation and/or ongoing operation of any such programs, scripts, or components, or to remove any such programs, scripts, or components, if in i-on's sole discretion they will interfere with the operation of the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of Web administration services.
explanation: The phrase "i-on's sole discretion" grants i-on significant power and is problematic. While i-on has a legitimate need to protect its server environment, this clause provides no objective criteria or appeal process for the Customer. i-on could arbitrarily deny approval, impose excessive fees, or remove software based on subjective reasoning. This gives i-on excessive control over the Customer's website functionality. The clause should include objective criteria for evaluating the impact of software, a process for appealing i-on's decisions, and/or limitations on the fees i-on can charge. For example, defining clear guidelines on what constitutes 'interfering with the operation of the Hosting Computer' would significantly improve the fairness and enforceability of this clause.

section: The Customer acknowledges that the Internet is an unreliable, unsecured, and error-prone network and agrees to hold i-on harmless for any interruptions in service to the Hosted Site or inability for users to reach or effectively use the Hosted Site that arises outside the scope of i-on's responsibilities as explicitly described in this Agreement.
explanation: While it's reasonable for i-on to not be liable for general Internet unreliability, the phrase "outside the scope of i-on's responsibilities as explicitly described in this Agreement" creates a potential loophole. The lack of a clearly defined service level agreement (SLA) within the main document means it's difficult to determine the precise extent of i-on's responsibility. The contract references a 'separate service level agreement', but without it being attached or explicitly incorporated, this clause could be interpreted to absolve i-on of responsibility for even significant downtime, as long as they can argue it stems from general Internet issues. To avoid ambiguity, the core agreement should include essential service level commitments or explicitly incorporate the separate SLA by reference, specifying its effective date and version. Without doing so, the Customer has limited recourse if the website is frequently unavailable due to issues that i-on could reasonably control.

section: The term of this Agreement for the Hosted Site shall commence upon April 1, 1999 and shall continue for a period of six (6) months, unless earlier terminated in accordance with provisions hereof. This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the Agreement, which notice must be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term. Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
explanation: There is a contradiction between the automatic renewal terms. The agreement states it renews for "one (1) or more one (1) month periods". The word 'more' creates confusion and is not appropriate. It is not clear what this means, it would be better to remove it from the contract as it adds no value and creates ambiguity.

section: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Agreement, no termination of this Agreement for any reason whatsoever shall relieve the Customer of the obligation to pay all amounts due to i-on and to make such payments on a timely basis.
explanation: This clause regarding payment obligations after termination is too broad. While it's reasonable for the Customer to pay for services already rendered, the phrase "all amounts due" could be interpreted to include fees for services not yet provided. For example, if the Customer terminates the agreement with 30 days' notice, this clause could be interpreted to mean the Customer is still liable for the next month's fees, even though i-on is no longer providing hosting services. A more equitable clause would specify that the Customer is only responsible for fees accrued up to the effective date of termination, plus any applicable early termination fees, if specified elsewhere in the agreement. Without this clarification, the clause is one-sided and potentially unenforceable.

section: The Customer agrees to indemnify and hold harmless i-on, against any lawsuits, claims, damages, or liabilities (or actions or proceedings in respect thereof) to which i-on may become subject related to or arising out of Customer's use of i-on's services, and will reimburse i-on for all legal and other expenses, including attorney's fees, incurred in connection with investigating, defending, or settling any such loss, claim, damage, liability, action, or proceeding whether or not in connection with pending or threatened litigation in which i-on is a party.
explanation: The indemnification clause is overly broad and potentially unfair. It requires the Customer to indemnify i-on for any claims "related to or arising out of Customer's use of i-on's services," even if those claims are caused by i-on's negligence or misconduct. A standard indemnification clause usually includes a limitation, stating that the Customer is only responsible for indemnifying i-on for claims arising from the Customer's actions, not from i-on's own errors or omissions. Without this limitation, the Customer could be responsible for indemnifying i-on even if i-on provides faulty service that leads to a lawsuit.

section: i-on expressly assumes no responsibility of the proper operation or maintenance of any of the Centrack site software that we authored by Imaginet and/or other third parties.
explanation: The word 'we' is incorrect in this phrase. It is unclear who 'we' refers to. It is better to clarify who authored the software.
